Entry.1:
The day for assemblingin Camp has come at last!

I had pictured it for many weeks past after I had finally made up my mind what I should do in the most momentous event in the history of the World €“ A European War! The great day which many of us have talked & thought for so long is now upon us and who can say what will be the outcome of 
the
this awful cataclysm!

What it has cost me to leave my darling Wife &Children God & myself alone know. It is all I can do to keep the tears back and the lump in my throat is very large!

But my duty has beenvery plain & clear & there wasonly one thing to do €“to place my services unreservedly before Major Onslow,my Officer Commanding the 9LH NSW M.R, after the Declaration of theWar on the 7th August 1914, &let him decide the rest.

My dearest Zara realized the situation at a glance & although we both knew all the sacrifices it meant, our joint resolution was that I should
sho
 and would do only one thing.

She & 
the
my children are the dearest things to me in the world & all I have lived for apart from trying toplay the gamethroughout my life.

What an experience if I come through &ifIdon't well 
...
I have done my duty & left a heritage for my children. When all is said & done what

else are we living for!

Dear Joyce & Geof can't realize of course what all this means & it is better that they cannot:they seem to be happy in the thought "well their daddy has gone to the War". How I love them all & so many think I am so hard andunsentimental. May it please God for me to return to them! The future is in His hands & I am content.

Poor dear Zara how hard it will be for her at times, in spite

of everyting, for there must come 
times
occasions when no one willcheer herand she will be all alone to think &to think.

As for me, I shall be busy all the time & there is nothing like work on occasions like this.

I have no illusions about War. I realize all itsdiscomforts & its terrors, but it has its sublime side too & thesatisfaction in having done ones duty is very greatto most men, at least this must be my satisfaction & my

consolation & it is.

My friend "Tony" Weaverhas undertaken to manage my legal affairs, assisted by my goodold friend DavidMoses (who has placed himself at my disposal at all times) & Zara 
who
I have made my Attorneys.

This alone has involveda great sacrificefor me after 10 years of hard work. I had at least worked up a good little practise. Mr Parsons myclerk will attend to the details & I have to letKenneth Wasbittgo, but I

hope he will return, if I do.

The Permanent Trustee Companywill be my executors, assisted by Zara, & Weaverwill be my solicitor in this event.

There have been many things to attend to but even these must have finality & so everything is done at last.

On the day of arrival in Camp there was little else to do except to settle down in quarters &see that



the men who had volunteered for servicewere comfortable.

Thehorse lines and other tents had to be pitched and eeryone worked with a will.

There were only a few officerswho reported amongstthem being Major Onslow, NettletonCoxSmith, Russell and Nichol €“ all the best fellows I should have said.

Major Holman was here too shaking things up in his best style &never sparing himself.

So far as I can see at present Major Onslow is to command, Holman is to be Adjutant,Vernon is to be 2nd in command, Smith O.C of one squadron, Granville

another & Captain irwin ofthe 3rd. I don't like Granville very much €“ he has a bad manner, but he mayimprove on acquaintance.

As to Onslow he is a fine fellow in everyway, but he has no initiative his deputy saves him all the time. I think he

feels very much the responsibilty which has devolved upon him & is wiselyfeeling his way all the time. He is a most responsiveman & will always do a thing if he thinks it is wise whether it comes direct from himself or not.

His position in private life is like my own (except he is mch better off) so far as leaving his wife & family are concerned.

Vernon the 2nd is one of the best fellows in the world. I really love

him: he tries to play the gameall the time: he has a good deal of confidencearising out of the fact that he has had War experience & many years service.

We are the greatestfriends &it has helped me alot having him of myside & toexchange confidences. He is leaving his wife & 3 children & depends entirelyon his pay:his business as an architect came to an end at once on the outbreakofwar
Entry.2:
Now I hear Onslow isto go into Hospital & to be operated on for appendicitis. Most unfortunate for him & for us. Iam indeed very sorry for he is a fine fellow.

Now I hope Major Onslow Thompson may be induced to take the command.

I should have said all the other officers are excellent fellows, keen & enthusiastic, but mostly very young & awaiting theirexperience just I am myself.
Entry.3:
It is now reported Major Thompson has refused to take command except he is allowed to make his own choice of officers €“ this would mean displacing several & he does notwant to do this, so it is probably he will not command after all €“ this will be a great loss & I know 
it
he would add 50%to my confidence. €“he is one of thefinest men & a born leader.
Entry.4:
Still much to be done & many men to be sworn in. This War has caught
 
Australia 10 years too soon &the result is that many men who have possed out are to be called in again (voluntary) as the 1894 Compulsory Cadets are still under 21 &cannot be takenexcept at their own wish & with their parents consent.

Some good men are presenting themselves & the selection will not be easy.

We are almost totally unequipped.

We are living in tents & there is no doubt this regular & plain way of living is most beneficial. We start workat 5.45 am & the mornings are very cold.

So far I have not been able to get beyond squad drill with my men, but this will not do them any harm. They are a good lot & will improveevery day.

All through my work I am everlastinglythinking of Zara & the children.The fellows often say I look

worried & I only wishI were not leaving them in this way €“ there is no doubt the path of dutyis often paved with very hard stones, but dear Zara is very brave.

I have received many letters from all sides, & there is no doubt the War has broken down all barriers & cementedall people irrespective of race creed or class.
Entry.6:
far the equipment has been very incomplete & with theexception of the men generally 
improving the
carrying out squad drill & the principal formations of dismounted troop drill there has been very little for them to do

Of course Camp Routine has been preserved in every way & the class of men erolled has been excellent



So far I have a most excellent lot in my Command€“ the Machine Gun Section& I want the very best too, for I recognize it is the most important part of the Regiment€“ 27 men in all & 35 horses 4 waggons & limbers 2 guns & a great lot of equipment.

The Regiment is 536 including 23 officers.
Entry.7:
Everyone has been very kind to me & I do appreciate their good wishes.

It helps me in this great wrench from my dear ones€“ Thank God they are keeping well & I see them whenever I can.

Zara is the bravest little woman in the world to me & my darling children, well I can't think too much about them€“ it unfits me for work & I really have lots to do.
Entry.8:
To day is Sunday & by invitation I went to the Neutral Bay Club at 5 P M where there was a big roll up of members to say "good bye"

About half a dozen fellows proposed my health & I replied, although I felt the great difficulty of properly doing so.

They presented mewith a set of razors Joyce with a gold bangle & Geof with a watch.

I felt very much saying good bye to so many who had really been my great friends & their last action has cemented the friendship between us much more.
Entry.9:
I have now seen EricVera ZilStella & Gladys.The two first had to leave for home & I felt very much on parting.

There is no doubt we have been drawn together very much durig the last few weeks on account of my going to the front.This in itself is a great thing to have achieved.

Ethel will be down latter.

I have had many letters from all sides.

Mrs L W Levey & Mrs B. D Cohen who have alwasy been my close friends came out to see me last Sunday week.

Mrs B. D & I had a long chat & there is no doubt she understands me€“ I am really very fond of her too.

Mrs L W. is very fragile & I would not be surorised to leaarn of her early demise.



My dear friend Mr Moses as usual has done all in his power to help me. He is indeed a real friend & nothing is too much for him to do. My indebtedness to him is very great. & he is a dear old fellow. I wonder whether I shall bespared to see him again.

Zara & I paid them all a visit & I kissed Mrs Moses when I left.

Dear little Debbie & I have been life long friends & nothing

has ever disturbed our relationship. She seems now to be happily married & has a dear little girl.

I know she understands me better than most people & I am very sorry I have not so far been able to have a quiet last talk with her before I go€“ perhaps I will later.

It is still hard to realize that one is taking part in the most momentous event in history & I keep saying what wiill the end be & where will we all be this time in 1915!
Entry.10:
Col. Meredith has just been appointed our new Commanding officer. He is at present a complete stranger to me, but I am determined to try & like him & I beleve he is a very good fellow, but my disappointment in not having Onslow 
&
or Onslow Thompson is very great.

Each would have given me personally great confidence & so much depends in this work on havingyour man

Onslow by the way is very much better but cannot hope

to get away with the
Entry.11:
Regt of L. Horse.

My disappointment is very great
Entry.12:
Every day here shows how much we are still waiting on equipment & I do not see how it wil be possible to
get
leave Australia for a fortnight.
yet

In the meantime the Germans seem to be prospering wost marvellously on land. Their well organized force is meeting with the success I felt certain would happen after their years of preparation



Evidently they had made up their minds about this Campaign for many years 
past
, but they cannot win in the end€“ that appears clearly impossible but there will be painfulloses in men & money before that end result is achieved.
Entry.13:
Istill continue to receive presents & cards from so many people & how there is absolutely nothing that I want.

I am sorryto have to say my dear friend Mrs L. W, Levey died on Saturday the
Entry.14:
exactly a week after she had been out to see me.

I made a special point of going out yesterday to attend the funeral & found afterward the Funeral was not till this afternoon & I cant go then.

Had a talk with Debbie on the telephone & she is coming out to see me on Thursday.

Had an unfortunate experience with one of the men to day who was insubordinate. I threated him with dismissal, but on consideration gave him a chance again, but never again€“ this is too big & important an enterprise to take any risks. I never had an experience like this before, but I feel I have done right in giving him another

change
chance.

I am Orderly officer tomorrow & I must end for tonight for I must be up at 5.45 am in the morning.

My darling & my children are however last on my thingsto do as I end this page, they must always be the same
Entry.16:
much has happened to me between the last time I have written a line and these that I hesitate to begin again but I know I shall
never
not regret having noted some of my experiences.
Entry.17:

There is nothing for me to do now, but waitdevelopments.

The Brigadier Onslow & Col Arnott are most annoyed at my treatment, but have advised me to stand by & wait events which I will do.

Poor Zara is very upset too & the position is most difficult in every way. One would imagine such a state of affairs was impossible after making all the sacrifices I have done.

Col Meredith now finds he has too many officers & it is necessary for some of us to go. I have just been thrown from a horse & the excuse is I am not efficient as a rider & he wishes me to resign, but I wont. However the same result is achieved & I have to go. I need hardlysay how upset I am at the great injustice which has been done to me

All agree with me in the Regiment, but there is no appeal.

I have been placed in a very awkward position which would not have arisen if Onslow

Suffice it to say that Colonel Meredith rejected me from the st Regt having to get some of his own officers in, as there was not room for all. I had the bad luck to bee thrown off a very fresh & unmanageable horse & this was the excuse.

Bad luck seemed to follow me after that & I was in Camp for 3 months with various Units & doing lots of work for v little pay, but in the end I did some good & thank heavens

it has turned out all for the best for now I am assured of my promotion & I am with Colonel Arnott & Major Onslow two of my own Brigade & men who understand me which Col Meredith never did. How I have suffered all these months from all all sorts of petty & other anxieties.

My darling little Wife has given me great encouragement & help, when things have seemed to go wrong.

My experience has been a splendid one & what



splendid loyalty I have had during this time. The men have been ready to fo anything
for me
& go anywhere for me at all times.

These men will give a great account of themselves when the day comes, but what of their training! The simply absorb the details as they are given, but the equipment is so slow in coming in & there is so much to do. The men are full of enthusiasm for the work.

The horses generally are a good lot &



will even up greatly as time goes on

The officers are a fine lot too. of course none of them have had much experience, but they are keen & intelligent. Better fellows one could not meet.

It is curious to observe the growth of Regiment. First there a single officer who has not bee able to get into a Regiment already established,& he is given charge of some men who are in the same position as himself then more come in from Barracks & more officers:



Some one voluteers for the job of quartermaster & then tents & men & officers join from day to day . One day a C.O is appointed & then things begin to move more rapidly The officers have to be chosen & 
some
so many apply that the task is a most difficult one. The red tape & conditions are in many case very arbitrary & many good men are lost & either drop out or go and volunteer elsewhere. Lots go to England at once.

Col. Arnott is now the C.O of the
Entry.18:
L H Regt A.I.F & he is doing his best to organize his Regiment on the best lines, but the task is indeed a great one. It is difficult to say who is to blame for the state of things but it nearly breaks one's heart to see things as they are.

No rifles or bombs & we are within a few days of sailing.The men are entirely raw & green & know absolutely nothing.

I have been given 2 M. Guns 20 years

old! It is almost incredible & the public know nothing of all this & even if they did they would not believe it.Perhaps they will some day! You can never tell.

On the
Entry.19:
we had to report to a L. H School under Major Holman at the Agricultural Ground & work commencedthere in earnest. I did not mind that, especially as I was able to get home every night & be with those who are so dear



to me. I have arranged all my affairs & have had long talks & conferences with Mr Moses who poor old fellow is devoted to my interests.Weaver too is very good, but he is careless & cannot,I am sorry to say.

The Colonel wants me to be
Entry.20:
in Command of a Squadron but now he has just as suddenly detailed me to M. G. work again & he has taken off a man who I believe to be a first class man at the job.

He is a Duntroon man & very smart but the Colonel has a rooted objection to the these Duntroon fellows: Goodness knows why!

One day the Colonel appeared at the School & we now know that it will not be very long before we have to go back to Camp; in the mean time we are entirely out of touch with the Regiment & there has been so much organization to do. When we return to the Regiment it will be like caos 

I have seen all the family.

This War has drawn us all together tremendously & I think they have all learnt or tried to understand me better than before. I confess I have been a problemfor some of them!

As for Zara & the children they have been nearer & dearer to me every day & as the time approaches for my departure the days are all too short

At last we have to leave on a definite day:€“ the
Entry.21:
December

Are we ready to go. Absolutely No!

It is really disgraceful of the Authorities to send us away like this: We are most improperly equipped. The men are untrained & our horses have only come forward the last week€“ and yet we are supposed to be going to make War against the best organized forcethe World has seen. It will be murder for many of us, but what

is to be done€“ Nothing!

Words are impossible to describe the dreadful state of affairs & yet one must smile & smile& try to play the game all the time.

I was at home on Sunday the
Entry.22:
of December for the last time.

All my spare
time
days the last 3 months have entirely been with Zara & the children & never a happier 3 months have I passed.There has been such splendid sympathy & understanding.











Many of my Uniforms & equipment are incomplete, nor can they be before I go! And I have not been paid! Incredible, but true.

Zara & the children came up to Camp on Wednesday & we all had tea in the open together.Zara packed up for me for tomorrow we leave Camp by Road for Sydney. My horses have been chosen & a nice three they are€“ Suttor helped me€“ he is a good fellow & we are the best friends.

Zara & the Children left by Car at 10 PM & were kindly driven down by Bruce Arnott all the way. The dear children were so tired, but so good & I loved having themwith me. The wrench between duty & my love for them is indeed a great one, but it has got to be seen through now & please goodness I will return to them full of maturity & experience.

I wonder what the future has in store!

I rang up Zara & she was very well, but disappointed I would not see her tonight, as I had hoped.

We left Camp at Holdsworthy at 3 PM on the
Entry.23:
We arrived 
at Strathfieldat 6 PM
at Colonel Arnotts Strathfield house 6 PM to bivouac. I slept by the telephone all night, as a consequence I had one hour's sleep.
all night.
The men were very cheerful for it rained in the night. They are indeed a good lot of fellows.

The Colonel had a very nice dinner for us & Mrs Arnott was very kind. We were up at 4 am & left there at 5 am & we got to the boat at

7.45 am. I should have been there 3 hours earlier, but the blocks were greasy & the horses were green, so I which I did.

The horses & men were embarked by 11.

Zara the children were not allowed on the Wharf till we were cast off & the planks were up.

The poor things suffered terribly & so did I. I simply could not speak at all, but it had to be gone through, as part of the job.

When on submits to the conditions of active service it is no bed of roses & that is the end of it.

The parting between those who are the dearest to me in the world is too great & sacred for me to say all I feel & I could not if I wished

Zara came out while we were in the stream but Icould only see her for a few minutes, as I was on duty all the time€“ having been appointed Adjutant. to the ship.

I have been through so much all day that my brain was dull & heavy to night & I could not suffer any more€“ all I know is that my wife & children were constantly in my thoughts.

Godhelp them & preserve them tillI return is my fervent prayer & in God do I implicitly trust.

We left at 6 am & I never saw them again although I had hoped we would not leave till 9 am & then I should have done soas Zara would have got a

a launch & come off.

Suttor who was detailed for Duty tried

Colonel Arnott missed the boat! What a state the poor fellow must be in.

We have now been at sea for 3 days. No wireless of any kind is allowed & we are entirely cut off from the world.

We expect in afew days to be in Freemantle

The sea has been remarkably calm I have been ill a little, but I have not been as bad as I thought.

The horses too are standing the strain splendidly, although some of the poor brutes are suffering keenly.

Everyone on the ship is very kind& nothing is too much trouble for the ships company.

I have as Adjutant but I do not mind this, as it keeps my mind well occupied.

I did notsee Eric or Stella on the wharf before I left, but ZaraDoy & Geof Gladys, Vera, Debbie Zil, Arthur Peel & others were there
Entry.24:
Today I have felt as fit as a fiddle€“ it is rough too. I can hardly believe myself. I am eating 3 meals a day & hardly feel the rocking motion at all.

Of course I am busy all day & have much to occupy my mind. Nothing of real importance occurred. A report got round the ship that Britain had met with another disaster€“ there was nothing in it at all. They call it "Latrine

wireless" & an excellent name too! I have publishedin orders that if any news arrives the men will know.

The job of Adjutant suits me well€“ Onslow is such a fine fellow & so easy to get on with.Altogether we are a happy lot here.

The men cleaned out stables all the morning & exercised the horses & in the afternoon all the saddlery was taken out & sorted & cleaned.

Rather a big job, but a so necessary one.

The men appreciate the splendid food they are having after the Camp cooking which is so much rougher

They are a jolly lot, but I do wish they were better trained & equipped but it is to be hoped they will be before they are allowed to take the field.
Entry.25:
We arrived in Fremantle on Saturday night after a remarkably fine trip from Sydney. We never lost a horse & I was only ill one day.

Everyone on board most friendly & we are a happy ships Company.

We are not allowed to use the Wireless at all except for Urgent Messages. Onslow is an excellent fellow to get on with.

I find the work as Adjutant keeps me busy & is very congenial

On Sunday we drew up at the Wharf & Onslow & I landed & went up to the Barracks. Everyone received us well & are most anxious to do all they can for us.

Freemantle is a flat dusty town of 25000 people.

Spoke to Dorris Rosenstam & Nellie Blaine. They were very surprised to learn I was there. Will see them later if possible.
Entry.26:
Met some of the 10th L H officersin Perth & them a fine lot.

Took 3 of them to dinner with me to Freemantleas I was up at Perth to-day. A very pretty town & the people I have met seem a large openhearted lot.

Saw GeorgeJoseph. He is not doing too well & I hear his wife is giving him a lot of trouble.

Wired to Zara every day & finally got 2 telegrams from her in reply. The dear

little girl & the children are well. May God protect them while I am away! I cannot think too much about how much it haunts me to leave them, but I have done the right thing & I am satisfied with that.

The
Entry.27:
officers had us to dinner at their Club tonight & then to the Theatre afterwards. They were most hospitable & we had a good evening.

Went to see Dorris & Nellie this afternoon & had a happy hour with them.

The home is a fine one & Dorris' two children dear little girls.

Altogether I was impressed with the possibilities of Perth.

We left Freemantleon the
Entry.29:
There were a few people on the Wharf to wish the troops off but there were no restrictions against the troops such as there were in Sydney.

George Joseph came down to the ship, but I had a very busy day & Iwas not able to give him any time at all.

The horses were Shipped quietly & without any hitch or confusion.

We lost 5 deserters at Freemantle

We left exactly at 5.30 PM & sailed S.W in order to meet the rest of the Convoy coming from Albany. Expect to pick them up next day.

Felt ill & squeamish, but I have still lots to do
Entry.30:
Several CourtMartialsto be held & I have to work them all up myself€“ it is an interesting experience.

Two N.CO have to be reduced for leaving the ship without leave

& being drunk. The work was done with all solemnity & with every care that the prisoners recd every thing in their favor. Both were convicted & it seems to have produced a salutary effect on the ship's discipline, which however has always been good.

Picked up the rest of the Convoy€“ about 18 ships to day A most interesting & historical event.

Wonderful how they have formed line€“ there are three with us 

The little Submarine AC2 hovers all round & as our escort We are
Entry.31: in the lead of the Right Division. It is hard to distinguish others on the ships, but I have seen several of the officers of the
Entry.32:
L H who I know.

The signaling between the ships is done most effectively both by flags & lights€“ the wireless is not used owing to the possibility of the E being near.

It is interesting to think what would happen if he did come. We

believe other escorts are all round us doing their job.

At night the sight of the ships in line in mid ocean is most impressive.

Day & night€“ it is just the same Something quite different to what one has ever seen before. The Submarine steams under her own all the time & easily on the surface can go 16 Knots an hour

The CO of the AMC has typhoid & we have signalledfor a female nurse on the Convoy but there is none in all the ships

Tomorrow Colonel Beeston comes to the ship to see what can be done with the case.
Entry.33:
This morning Colonel Beestonrowed over in mid ocean from the Berrima. The whole Convoy had to stop & the sight & event was most interesting.

All the ships had to slew round & await the order to go ahead. It took fully an hour to accomplish the

object.

Major Onslow has written very decently to the Minister of Defence about me. There has been no occasion, I have simplytried to do my duty.
all the time

I am feeling ever so much better.

Received a parcel of books: they must be from Myers, but no card came with them. I will write to him anyhow.

I am now on the Indian ocean for the first time. We expect to see Colombo in a week.





I wonder how my dear ones are indeed!
Entry.34:
Have paid all the men 1/- per day for 20 days. This is the rule for Troops on Board Ship

Terribly hot & the horses & all of us are suffering a good deal.

Had some gramaphone the other night€“ it was a beautiful evening & with the lighted transports all round the scene was most romantic.
Entry.35:
Last night as we were going to Messa message came through from the Flagship that Duncan Campbell a NZ trooper had died & that he would receive a Military Funeral at 8 PM. Major Onslow & I announced the fact to the Troops & at once a gloomsettled down on the ship At the apptd hour all the fleet stopped & it was indeed a solemn moment to see all these ships in mid

Ocean pay their last respect to a soldier who 14 or 15 thousands of them never knew but who at the same time was one of themselves.

We all wondered what were the actual feelings of those men on the death boat the lights of which we could see flickering a mile away. This was the 
first
second death on record amongst us. It is sad to think his people are in ignorance & must be for some time to come
Entry.36:
We had a humorous day with sports, half of which we could only finish, as the management was
not good
indifferent this was to celebrate crossing the Line this morning.

Later we received notice that another man had died on another boat & his burial would be at 6 PM with Naval honors. I went on the bridge & watched the body being committed to the deep€“ it was indeed another solemn moment. The fleet stopped for 10 minutes & then on



again at full speed€“ we expect to be in Colombo tomorrow and so everything passes.
Entry.37:
We arrived at Colombo early to-day & anchored in the inner harbor.We are to stay there 24 hours at the most.The ship is anchored 2 miles at least from the shore & the row in is rather trying on a choppy sea.

I had to go off to send cables & to attend to other business & had not much time to look round as I had to return for dutyat 5 PM to allow Onslow to go off to dinner. I rowed out alone with two niggers who sang

to keep up their spirits as they rowed in the heat.

The town was most interesting to me in the short glimpse I had of it but I am in hopes of seeing something more of the place tomorrow.

First paid a visit to Flagship with Onslow & saw B/Major. This ship is most elaborately fitted & I sawmany fellows I knew on board€“ amongst them was Shellshear, who could not reveal his joke, but I gipped him about Colonel Beeston& his & this quietened him at once. Everything was bustle & activity

there.

I had charge of ship tonight & the way the coolies worked all night was most interesting to me. They are indeed a most fascinating people & every phase of life absorbed byme €“It was so entirely new.
Entry.38:
Three other officers & myself got away earlyto day & we went round the town & its outskirts in a Car. We had breakfast at the famous Gall Face

Hotel,then for a ride in a rickshaw

We went through thenative quarter & the the markets & then back to town. I bought dear Zara some blouses & a kimono

I sent her a cable & wrote her three long letters. Other letters & post cards to others. I was in hopes of receiving a reply to my cable, but alas I did not

It is now a month since I left them all & how long it seems! I do wishindeed I could hear



from
Zara
home, but I suppose it is not to be. I do miss them terribly & they are ever in my thoughts

I do hope she receives safely my small gift.

I spent a most interesting½ day in Colombo & came away well satisfied with my experience. How Zara would love it all. It would appeal to her absolutely on all its phases, but a week would be enough I think really
Entry.39:
We left Colombo at 9 am on Friday.

Tonight there was a real scare. About 9 PM a signal came through that the Enemy had been sighted.

I went up on the Bridge & another signal came through what we were to do in case we were attacked. I was kept going till the small hours putting out lights etc. As I stood on the Bridge every minute expecting an attack my thoughts were full &strange, but nothing happened after all, but the mental phrase & anxiety were there just the same

The ship steaming through the night with signals by Morse passing and re-passing was weird 
& absorbing
€“ I will never forget the experience. The Submarine had its orders to attack at once. The fleet were to scatter & assemble at a point named.

Our course has been changed twice since the scare & we are now proceeding up the Indian Coast on the West & we have no idea yet where were are going to finally land.

In Colombo the town houses of the chief residents are ideal Wide Halls, Lawns & fine gardens everywhere.

The labor trouble is resolved there, The Cingalese are splendid servants.

I have never seen anything like the smartness of the clerks in the Telegraph office & they were all natives too. They could give our fellows in Australia many points.
Entry.40:
Another death on the Themistocles€“ this is the 5thdeath at Sea€“ 4 being on the one ship alone.

Onslow not at all well & he has a high temperature.

De Low removed from the command of the Transport A35. He certainly is a most peculiar fellow & I can understand anything happening to him.

Of course I got no reply to my cable at Colombo at it is now nearly a month since I heard from home€“ most trying, but it is just what I knew it would be, so I must not complain

I suffer a good deal with this wretched nausea & it so unfits one for work.

I have a very poor batman I lost Reid under peculiar circumstances & another officer has got him now. Reid went to quarantine for about 2 months & wanted

his discharge: in the meantime I had to ger another man & Reid not getting his discharge another officer then took him on.

I dont think I mentioned that I got my promotion as from the 16thDec 1914. I am now
Entry.41:
in Command of B Squadron: I was temporarily in command only of the M.G Section but did my best to put everything in good shape & order there to again hand it over to the officer €“Thorne who succeeded me.

There was little doubt from my observation on the Flagship€“ Ulysses that the officers there were by no means pulling together

The two Doctors€“ Finn & Kenny are hard citizens€“ one has just said he was going to take a mans horse when he got killed & he meant it too. These Doctors care as much about others as their dam instruments do. They rejoice in cutting up & looking after themselves! Curiouslythey are not bad fellows & one gets a lot of fun out of them on the whole,

We are now off the Coast (West) of India steering in the direction of Aden

We are keeping well out of the beaten track, in case there should be any of the Enemy's stray cruisers round.
Entry.42: Two more men died at sea to-day. This is the
Entry.43: from the Themistocles& the sports had to be suspended while the funerals were proceeding.
Entry.44:
Reported at noon that a strange cruiser was on the starboard bow. It was some time before we could make her out & not before the submarine was sent off at full speed to investigate€“ a very interesting interlude. It turned out the cruiser was one of the



Royal Indian Marine with troops on board going in the direction of Aden. She must have thought also we were a strange sight.

The Wireless has caught a message from the Japanese Flagship 40 miles away that Suez is being attacked by the Turks. The Flagship is the Fujiyama.
Entry.45:
Had some fun to-day. Kenny the M.O. told the troops not to obey my order to wear Cholera Belts, as he did not believe in them. I pretended to make a lot out of this & got Onslow to agree to send a message to Col. Beeston P.M.O asking for instructions in view that ships orders had been held up to ridicule. I went up to the Bridge & did the thing in regular style€“ all except sending the message!

Kenny believed I had done it all right & we had a good laugh.

There is a tremendous expenditure of water on board (at least 50 tons per day are being used) by the 376 men & 285 horses.

Onslow is better again & has escaped what seemed a certain case of typhoid. This is a great relief to me & to all concerned. He is really a fine fellow.

We have now lost 4 horses & we are nearing Aden where we hope to be at noon tomorrow.

No one is to land & mails are to be sent off

by the Ulysses. I will only send dear little Zara a postcard, as this is the only chance of her getting the communication quickly. I wonder how she & the children are!

We keep up a regular supply of men in the Hospital€“ all sorts of accidents happen to men & the Drs keep very busy always. Last night one man's hammock dropped off the hook & he hurt his head & back on the end of the table.

We certainly have been a long time at sea€“ 5 weeks to-day€“ a week Sydney to Freemantle€“ a fortnight between Freemantle & Colombo & a week between Colombo & Aden. We stopped 1 week at Freemantle.

Am working up F. S Rep, but it is really very difficult to do any solid reading on board & I thought I could do so much too, before I started.

It is possible we may be fighting the Turks in a fortnight.
Entry.46:
We arrived at Aden at 10. am. The Ayrshire was 30 or 40 miles behind, but there were 17 ships in the Convoy & it was a fine sight when they all dropped anchor together. Aden itself is something quite different to any place in Australia. The headland was desolate & barren & the great range of Hills called BehelNansam was most precipitous€“ the highest point being 1726' high. On the top of one was a flag station, & on another

was a Turkish Fort. A few Somalis came out to trade, as we were really anchored right outside the outer harbor.

I had to go off to the Flagship on military work in the ship's boat & I admit at once, although it was an interesting experience, it was also a dangerous one€“ the Captain of the ship said afterwards he ought not to have let me go. I had to jump into the boat as she came up on a wave &
the
a big sea was

running.
was a very big one indeed
When I got to the Ulysses I had to climb up a ladder to get on board & down again to come back again. I felt very tossed up when I got back to the ship, but "cracked hardy" all the time & so did Suttor who did not feel too well either.

I met the Brigadierin charge of the Convoy Colonel Monash€“ a Jew€“ & he seemed a very decent fellow. I also had a long talk to Shellshearwho gave me the latest news, but there was

none of outside events: we are all very disappointed at being so much cut off from the outside world, when so much is happening in it.

I also met some of my old friends of the 13thBattalion who all seemed glad to see me.

Onslow is still not too well & I am a little anxious about him.

I got a telegram from my darling Wife which had not reached me at Freemantle€“ it was to congratulate me on



my promotion€“ I only wish I could hear how the 3 of them were & Shellshear said the same to me to-day.

Nothing of any importance in Convoy orders which were forwarded to-day.

We are still a very happy lot on board & quite contrary to what they are on the Flagship, so I hear.

We sailed at 5 PM from Aden€“ no one was allowed on shore.

All we could see of the habitations were Barracks & guns.

There seems to be very extensive military accomodation for this other outpost of the Empire.

We caught up with the Persic, the Suevic& the Ceramic which had left us one day before we got to Colombo. We have no idea of the reason of their going.

Shellshear said that they all had great respect for Monashon board & that he was a very able man.

I sent Postcards from here€“ Aden€“ to all at home. They will all be censored & sent from Port Said at the earliest.

They have a great crowd of officers on board the Flagship. They wear Khaki trousers & white shirts & stars on their shoulders!
Entry.47:
€“ Sunday.

Church service for R.Cs at 6.45 am and for C of Es at 11. AM

Passed two P & O Liners €“one going to Australia & the other to Japan. Both ships saluted the Convoy. Truly wish I had been able to send a few messages home by the former.

We are in the Red Sea & every place now is full of interest & association.

I got up at 2.30 am to see the lights of Persia

Then there were other lights in the red Sea likely carried on by Turkey, but now occupied by Britain as part of the spoils of War.

We passed more ships to day than on all the other days of the voyage€“ now 5 weeks€“ put together. Amongst them was a fast converted Canadian (C. P. S.) Cruiser patrolling this portion of the sea & going along at a great rate. She signalled good luck to the Convoy€“ a man died

on the Ceramic to-day. The 3 White Star Boats are again with us & in line on the port Division.

Curiously the sea has been rougher here than anywhere else so far & it is the Red Sea!

My dear ones are constantly in my thoughts & I do wish I could hear how they are, but I have to grin & bear it.
Entry.48:
Anniversary Dayin N.SW & I forgot all about it till the day was nearly over.

We€“ our ship€“ I mean have fallen out of our Estate, as a Black Germanhas pushed us out of position & got in front of us in the Line. We are using Bengal Coal & this partly accounts for the trouble.

How the Captain cursed & we all felt being beaten very much.

News of a British 

Victory on the North Sea has just reached us.

Onslow is not at all well€“ I rubbed him last night. I feel & we all do€“ very anxious about him.

I have now quite settled down to the work of the Adjutant & would not mind taking on the Regiment after my experience.

Very angry with Suttor for his irresponsible ways & I gave Hession a doing tonight also

Kenny the M O also made me very annoyed & altogether I had a trying day.

We are nearing Suez The Sea is very calm. I have no batman & have others looking after me€“ this on account of being transfered back to B. Squadron
Entry.49:
We have broken down in the small hours & are now about 30 miles behind the restof the Convoy with the exception

of the "Ayrshire" which does not count€“ a great disappointment.

Another important incident is that the troops have been accused of stealing Ships Stores€“ the allegation was of the Chief Steward. It fellthrough completely& we are now waiting for the Captains apology in writing.It appearsthe Chief Steward has been selling the liquor to our troops & now to cover up the deficiency he has blamed the troops for stealing the amount. We. have

jamed Courtof Enquiry & K. R's downthe Captains throat & he is shivering in this shoes. We have been most serious in our manner & altogether we have had a rare old lark.

The Chief officer is enjoying the fun too for he is deadly opposed to the Captain.

Early this afternoon we got among small Islands on the red sea & then on to the Sinai peninsular with the Mn in the



distance. They ranged up to nearly 8000' & were a fine sight. I saw the place where the Jews were supposed to have crossed the Red Sea & as I stood on the Bridge & gazed into the desert foreshores& the Mountains behind my mind was full of all sorts of thoughts of the days in the distant past.

We are still behind the rest of the Convoy.

We presented the Prize Money this afternoon
for
won on the 11thinst

&
Entry.50:
inst. Not many ships have been passed today.

I find the Uniforms made by R. Reid & Co are absolutely disgraceful.

Westons groom had 40 odd beersin Freemantle!

Had some good lessons in Knot tying to-day. & I had some fun trying afterwards to demonstrwhat i could do & I could not!

The A. M. C. won the tug of war.

We are now getting into the first lot of cold weather.

and the effect is very strange after the extreme heat.
Entry.51:
We met the Convoy at 4 am at Suez€“ a beautiful sight in the early morning.

We anchored here all day. I made 2 visits to the Ulysses on official business & met a lot of officers. I had tea with Col. Beeston & sent 
them
home two three postcards
home
. They will not however be posted till Port Said, although it is quite

easy for the Military Authorities to deal with them at once€“ this is a way they have in the Army!

Col Beeston is a fine little fellow & we quite enjoyed his association while he was on board with us. He told me to-day he fell into the water, boarding the Themistocles at Aden€“ this was the same day as my own roughexperience. He was nearly drowned, but was pulled on board by the seat of his pants. This is the ship on which all the deaths have

occured€“ he told me the M.O. had his tail down completely, everything was doing wellbut that he had now put an end to the trouble.

Bice is on board the Ulysses suffering with an appendix, but has not been operated on yet€“ I don't quite like Bice& he doesn't understand me.

Suez is a large town & very busy at present.

The NZ troops have landed here.

Word & orders have just reached us of the misbehaviour of

the troops in Cairo of the 1stDivision & that all leave was going now to be refused to us. This is how the actions of a few affect the many. Most damnable & we are much annoyed.

There is little doubt after looking round the various ships we are very comfortable here, although the other boats are more luxurious.

The sea is as calm as a milk pond here & all the Transports lighted up made a beautiful

sight.

News just received that there has been fighting up the Canal 4 miles from here & we have our bridge sandbagged with a M. G, also in readiness. We also have an armed Guard for emergencies.

Onslow is better.

Saw Col.Monashto-day.

My two horses keep well€“ I have still one to to chose from B Squadron.

I can't realize that I am at Suez. It will be so strange to talk of all these experiences if ever I get back.

Col. Beeston told me that he had more experience during this voyage than during the whole of his life before & I can well understand it.

Kenny has "gone off". I don't quite trust him now€“ he is too irresponsible & bloodlike . You can seldom him to do anything correctly & he is a terrible loafer in many military ways, You have to live with a man to know him.

I have settled with Kenny€“ he was under a misapprehension & everything

is now all right between us€“ I told him this was not the time for misunderstandings & he was pleased I spoke about the matter.
Entry.52:
Weston & Kenny went on to the Ayrshire last night. Things are from happy over there & they have given us all the prestentconcern.

The Colonel seems to have done nothing except harass all his officers & there is no loyalty at all. Onslow is much upset & so are we all, but we are determined to pull together & remedy things, when we

land. Westons description of his experience was most amusing, although it had its serious side. He had to go & come back in a "bum" boat. The Arabs were funny fellows & the noblers of whisky we gave them when they got back would have killed most men, but they drank them right off.

Today we started for Suez at 10 am. We were
Entry.53:
in the order of the procession of ships. We are advised that we may have some



fighting or rather that the Turks are not faraway& are likely to fire on us. We have therefore protected the Bridge with Bags & Bales & mounted the MG on the forward deck.

What a day of interestit has been. We got into the Canal people cheering us at Suez as we passed there. Then row after row of entrenchments on both sides of the Canal€“ they were beautifully made & were manned by Gurkas , Sikhs, Punjabis, N Z Troops & Britishers, all

cheered us as we passed in turn. We could speak& signal to many.

Then we passed Warship after Warship &
stood
the Guard presented arms. There was much cheering& enthusiasm shown & the kinship was strong.

At 3.30 PM we pulled up€“½ the Convoy€“ & anchored for the night. At this point 7000 Turks were seen a day or so ago. We will move if they fire on us & a French War

ship is standing by in case of trouble.

It was my decision to mount the Gun & every boat did the same, so I was pleased I had suggested the idea.

Mails close for Port Said tomorrow & I have written a long letter to my dear little Girl with a lot of Post cards & loving hope she gets them safely.

Tonight we pulled up in the Big Bitter Lake. What a beautiful night! but very cold on the water.
Entry.54:
To-day we started into the Canal again & almost at once we came upon scores of guards of Gurkas, Sikhs with splendidly fortified post. They were just perfectly constructing exactly as they are laid down in the Books. We saw young striplings of Englishmen in command.

What splendid fellows these Indian troops are & how proud men must be to lead them & I will bet they go anywhere.

Every yard was of interest.

N Z Troops & others from S. A were there too & made a good show.

About 10 or 11 we all got right into it just before we came to Ishmalia €“ another place of interest & where the Khedive has a summer residence. There were many troops there too.

About 11 am we saw some patrols comingin retiring one at a time & all the trenches being manned & with other troops in reserve. There seemed to be hundreds of mounted troops

coming in to the attack & there was a little excitement. We mounted the M. Gun, & put the men into the lying firing position & all was eagerness & keeness for a scrap. It was a splendid
little
experience& one that one of us will never forget. All the details of the trenches, barbed wire entanglements & fortified houses were perfectly built according to the Rules as laid down. Even the horses and camels of which we saw numbers

were entrenched, so were the living tents of the officers & men.

We heard tonight that one British & officerhad been killed coming in at night after their aeroplane had broken down.

It was really most exciting seeing these hundreds of horsemen bearing down on us & the Patrols coming in. This was the first taste of the very real thing.

The expressions on some of the men's faces were extraordinary€“ most of us laughed,

suppose for want of something else to do.

I know I felt quite calm & elated with a fearful spirit of fight & aggression predominant. Quite a different feeling to any I have ever really experienced before. Any moment any of us might have been right into it & it really is hard or even another obliged when you are moving as we were on the Canal all the time

We would dearly loved

to have stopped & had a proper scrap.

We passed several men of War & we turned out the Guard& saluted with present arms.

The "Swiftsure" & "Ocean" were two of the largest vessels & it helped one to realize England's power of Empire.

The Admiral on the first named turned out & returned our salute. As close were, we could have almost jumped on to her decks

How some of these experiences must open the eyes of the boys from outback.

I must say at once to-day's experiences were some of the most interesting of my life.

Although no under fire actually I can say that it might have been opened any minute€“ and the feeling is one of excitement & exhilaration rather than otherwise.

I suppose this is occasioned by reason of the fact that it seemed some of winding up to our long voyage & it seemed in the nature of things.

We got to Port Said about 8 pm. Suttor, Kenny, Finn Weston & I went off on leave to see the sights of the town & we saw
some
of them.

It certainly is one of the worst places in the world, Everywhere one is the flamboyant cry & everything & anything

is done if you pay for it.

Hotels keep open all night & the shops will do the same if you want them to!

All dress here as Egyptians with the Fez etc.

I sent a long letter to Zara by the Pilot who was a very pleasant Frenchman with a low refined voice & full of pessimism as to the result of the War.

A Lot of the men broke leave here, but none got drunk€“ all returned in the small hours & were placed

under open arrest for trial next day.

The Colonel came on board the next day. He is very very jumpy & he is giving us a lot of anxiety. Onslow & all of us cannot understand his ways & manners at all

Something heavy is on his mind. We are all much concerned for he is one of the best fellows in the world. He is very thin & worn.

The boat had many bum boats round it with people selling all sorts of

things, & musical honors.

Every minute was full of interest.

The men & women coal here & it is wonderful the work they do€“ nothing like it have I seen anywhere. They are merely like flies on a plank.

Saw one or two officers Hogue & others from the Suevic.

Beautifully cool weather of course this is winter.

Heard to day the attackwe saw yesterday ended in 5 NZ & 30 or 40 Lancashires being killed,

We seem to have now

lost touch with AE2.

Left Port Said at 3 PM. A beautifully calm trip to Alexandria where we arrived at 6 am on the
Entry.55:
"Bum" boats all round us in a few minutes & the place seems a big one from the boat view.

Had a Court Martial yesterday. I was Prosecutor. The prisonerpleaded guilty & was fined £2 for leaving the ship without permission.

Kenny & I had a passage

at arms€“ he being one of the Court. Suttor presided & Stephenson was the other member.

Onslow is better.

The situation at the front grows no better nor is there anything new to chronicle.

We feel we are now getting into touch with the real world of things, but I cannot realize I am so very far away from my dear ones & from Australia.

Went off to the Ulysses with Onslow, but all the Staff had gone on by train the night before.

We then went to the Ayrshire & saw Col Arnott & others, but I must confess I have many misgivings about the future of the Regiment: I don't like Colonel Arnotts condition at all.

Sent a cable to Zara per Weston who when he returned with an account of his experiences was most amusing.

We also visited the Suevic & had some "fiz"€“ I have hardly drunk anything else except Champagne

since I have been on board.

Met Verge, Oatley & Ryrie of the
Entry.56:
L H.

The first person I saw when I got up on deck was young Hill.Spoke to the Brigadier and Major Lynch. We tried to get leave for the men, but could not manage it.

The Coinage question is very difficult in all the new places & the language barrier is also very great. French is spoken here generally

This place is one of the oldest in the world The harbor is full of

captured German's Ships.

I saw Barney Somerville & had a yarn to him.

I am told that the shops and streets are beautifully laid out & everything is done in the Hotels on the best lines.

We will probably go to Heliopolis by train tomorrow.

We came into the Wharf out of the stream at 5.30 PM Onslow had all the men fallen in & out them on their honor & granted general leave

till 10.15 PM

He placed a strong guard on. I went with young Asher who was acting as disemabarkation officer to see that the men returned in proper time. Asher lost his way on the wharves at about 11 PM & instead of seeing Alexandria I saw nothing at all. However the general night's experiences were interesting, but I had a bad fall on the wet cobble stones of the wharf.

Next day 105 men left for Maadi at 10 30 am Therre was much to do get them

away to time. Owens & Maulant got very drunk & were placed under arrest.

We are indeed very weak on N.C.O.

The next team left at 6.30 PM & we were able to clean up the ship beautifully.

Felt very much having to say good bye to the Chief officer Captain & others€“ the next day the 3/2/15, but all these things have got to have some finality.

We slept on board the night of the
Entry.57:
Feby 1915 & slept in

too, the first time for many weeks This was after the troops except the Rear Party had left.

We, Onslow & I had to see that everything was cleared right out of the ship in the way of stores equipment etc as a Certificate had to be given. We decided after this was done to have a few hours to ourselves in Alexandria, as we certainly had earned it. We left the ship at 1 PM. Then we drove to the

Hotel with a guard as we had to take away from the Fort3 prisoners of ours who had been arrested the night before.

Then we dispatched the Guard & prisoners to Maadi, after which we had lunch, met Finn & Kenny & withthem for a most beautiful drive visited the Catacombs Pompeys Tomb & Pillar

Words fail to describe the interest these places had for me
Entry.58:
Back for dinner at 8 PM. Then to a music hall showwhich was very poor. The morality of the City is very bad & the sexual relations are very flamboyant

How I wish I could hear from home & my darlings€“ this idea permeates everything I do & think.

We intended to do the "wicked sights" tonight, but were too tired & besides we had seen so much already.

Had a beautifully comfortable night's rest in a bed for a change.

We had to leave Finn & Kenny behind here, as they were going to a different Camp. We were very sorry to part indeed.

Onslow is a fine fellow to travel with & we get on famously.
Entry.59:
Left for Cairo at 9 am & arrived there at 1.30 PM

Went to Shepherds for instructions for G. O. C. Hdqr are there.

Saw a Colonel on the Staff a very

smart fellow & he gave us all the information we wanted. We will have some lunch & leave for Maadi at 2.20. PM.

Arrived at Camp at 3 P.M. Had to walk through a very pretty suburb first of the same name alone. Then into the desert sand. This is indeed a new experience, but you get used to anything in time.

I am camped with Rutledge & I wonder how we will get on together. He is aMajor & I his Captain &
Entry.60:
in command. I doubt if the experiment with him will be a success for he is very weak in his work & has rather lost himself with promotion, but I am determined to do all I can to help him & the Regiment.

The Colonel seems better in spirits, but he is still not too well. All seem so

scared of him & there is no real sympathy between him & his officers€“ which is a bad thing for all concerned. I do hope Onslow will be able to right things€“ he is the only man who can & I know he means to try
Entry.61:
The Camp is a very large one. I am still & have a lot to do arranging everything. So far we have everything very importantly arranged

An Arab Contractor&

his servants do everything by contract at so much per day.

It is extraordinary how these people fuel upour ideas & we theirs€“ I suppose it is a question of the dominant race.

On every side are matters & things which interest me

I am sorry to say the Regimental officers are rather a mixed lot & there is not that cohesion & sympathy between us that one expects

& works for. However I have Onslow Higgins & Suttor as friends & am content.

I forsee trouble with Rutledge who is very unsound & bluffs his way through. However I endeavor to play the game with him, if he will let me, but he is difficult to get on with.

The people here are very friendly to us all. They are very kind & hospitable & have offered us baths whenever we

want them€“ this is a great boon after a day on the desert.
Entry.62: Received my Australia mail the latest letter was dated
Entry.63:
was dearest Zara.

All was well with them: she was very lonely & sad. The dear children also wrote me sweet little letters

I got letters also from the other members of the family except Zillie. They were very kind to Zara after I left.

The letters brightened me up greatly.

Have not yet decided whether to send for Zara & the children yet. Would dearly love to have them, but the question is not easy of solution movements & the fast approaching summer.

Suttor & I are both exercised in our minds about the same matter. He wantsme to cable for Zara alone, but

I will not hear of the idea.

I feel 20 years younger since my letters arrived.
Entry.64:
2 14 

Have constantly been in Cairo. I am very laid up on account of the pay due not yet being paid. We are all the same. This treatment is very disgraceful & it is almost incredible thatwe should have been sent away without being paid these sums due€“ so many of the men have been

treated in the same manner & I feel very sorry for them & I have done all I can to remedy the matter.

Cairo is very bright at night. The Hotels are full of attractive women & men in Uniform these days. The scene is a brilliant one often & I only wish Zara was here to enjoy it too.

Perhaps she will be later

I met some very nice people named

€“ having letters of introduction to them & N.Bentivitch from Jack Myers

They were rather cold at first, but as the evening progresses they all opened out. Bentivitch I have read of for years in the Jewish Chronicle. He is a lawyer & at once struck me as clever. the others are known here very well & are Bankers & consequently very wealthy.

Their home is a very large one & inter alia



they have a synagogue on the premises. I spent a very pleasant evening there.

i also met on the same day a Mr Jessula who spoke 9 languages & is a resident here.I went roundthe town with him & he pointed our & explained many things.

I also visited the synogue which is a splendid building & a fine piece of work inside I was introduced to the President€“ a certain

Pasha who invited me to call on him He has been a soldier & I may do this if I have time.

Last week I visited the Pyramids & the Sphinx at Mena I climbed up Kheops & went inside to the various chambers. The whole experience was most interesting & I was absorbed in all its associations & splendor. They are most monumental works

indeed. I shall forget having been there. One has little idea of the immensity of them all. The Climb up is hard one. Two Arabs pulled pushed & hauled me up. A magnificent view at the top. After we got down.

I went through the passages to the Kings & Queens Chambers. These passages are on inclines& it would be impossible to get up & down them without assistance.

of some kind. Already 2 Australian troops have been killed trying to go up or down & I can easily understand how this would happen.

I have written very long letters to my darling wife & only hope all is well & that she will get them all right.

Poor old Mr Moses is in my thoughts & I wonder how he is.

The Colonel seems better & things are proceding in a more even way.

Met a Mrs Bentley. She had a type of red hair & she dressed in mauve, so I concluded she "knew things".

It is hard to realize when one sees so many people in Town that we are so near the theatre of War, but I feel certain that all these men who are enjoying life, will

do their job when the time comes & there is no reason why they should not have some "play" after a hard days work.

Have met Generals Birdwood & Walker. Both fine men. Their methods are direct, but they are gentlemen all the time.

Have not seen Kenny or Finn at all.

Met Stokes at the Hotel. His wife was there. It is astonishing the number of officers wives who are here.

I visited some Mosques, the Citadel some Indian soldiers who had been woundeddown the Canal & Tombs to day€“ Sunday.

In the morning came with me & in the afternoon Mrs Stokes,Mrs King (a pretty little woman just married)

& Stokes. Altogether I had a good day.

In the evening, the Colonel Onslow & Suttor dined with me at the Continental. We had dinner the night before with Onslow, passed a good evening, as the wine was good. "Fizz" is a common thing these days, but I cant afford it myself. Onslow is always so kind & liberal.

Had to do some official business this afternoon & we

2 or 3 hundred of the Turks who had been captured on the Canal. They are a motley crew. They were captured in Kas-el Nil Barracks, an enormous place.

The wounded Indians brought home to one the stern realities of War. They are fine fellows, with no complaints One is compelled to feel more & more every day how small & insignificant he is.

I have just been appointed Commander of the Brigade M Guns & it has appeared in Brigade & Regimental Orders. it is a big job & I feel the responsibility of the position very much indeed. Most fellows think it a a big thing. Onslow's Cousin from the Indian Army is at present helping me in the work of training. He is a fine fellow& quite young. He is on General Birdwoods staff.

This work takes me away from the Squadron a lot, but I am at present on its strength, although practically on the Staff. Things will probably develop on this behalf shortly & I am simply waiting events.

I have seen Vernon, & many others of the
Entry.65:
L. H. They all seemed very pleased to see me & they are a fine lot of fellows. These days Cairo is indeed the meeting

place of Australians.
Entry.66:
I have been very slack in entering up this diary owing to being more or less busily engaged & having so much to do & think about.

The Brigade training took up a lot of time. I find Onslow of the
Entry.67:
Bengal Lancers who is assisting me & who is A.D.C. to General Birdwood a very fine fellow€“

he is like all the Onslows, so easy to get on with & he knows his job too.

Had another visit from the General himself, but he is very quiet & watcheswithout worrying me at all€“ he soon sees things, as they are.
Entry.68:
Visited Sahara with a partyof fellows

from the Brigade€“ about 15 guns in all We went through Memphis & several most interesting Mastabas & tombs. A great day for all of us. I am lost in wonder at the historical side to all & the time oh the time it all means. The day before I visited the Egyptian Museum Which I suppose is the richest in the world in ancient Egyptian antiquities I found that by going alone, I was able to do
Entry.70:
much
& think so much better.

I dined with Smith Edmonds & Kater at the St James Cafe & we afterwards spent the evening together & had a jolly time

The Colonel seems better, but still far from his real self€“ he is very & you never know whereyou have him.However on the whole I get on with him very well, but his condition does not make for the com-

petency of the Regiment& it causes us all a lot of anxiety.

Onslow feels the position keenly€“ in many ways he reminds me of poor fathers ways, just at the time when he was so worried & worn with mental anxieties.

We are getting used to the Desert, but takes a lot of getting used to all the same.

The other night Suttor & I were

in town together. We were quite sober, but we had dined well! Missed the last tram & caught a motor out. We were very tired & the car broke down in Old Cairo. We did not bother but later were awakened by Chisholm & Hordern with a sentry standing over us. They had dashed by & seena Car on the road pulled up & came back. There we were fast asleep, but

by Jove they were good Samaritans!

Have cabled several times to Zara during the last few days. First advising her not to come on account of uncertainty; then position improved & I cabled her to come when I found so many other wives here.

The position got worse meantime & finally I cabled her to go to England. This she is now

doing but I am afraid I will not see her & I am terribly disappointed, but what can I do. We may leave any day now.

She will get letters from me at Colombo fondly advising her. I have written Oscar who will do all he can I know & meet her & the children on their arrival in London.

It will be fine for Zara having the trip€“ there is every

reason for her doing so. She will feel she is no so far away, but Heavenknows it will be far enough.

She will realize her ambition & I hope will have a most enjoyable trip for she leaves tomorrow the
Entry.71:
I wish I were there to see her excitement bubble & happiness & I only trust she will have a good trip & may my

darling children also keep well. Mrs Suttor is
keeping
coming too.

The Guns are making progress.

Things are indeed moving at present & already several Battalions have left Egypt.

I think we are now to go to Turkey as the Dardanels are being forced & already are reduced by the Allied Fleet 

Had dinner with Broadbent last night.

How I have enjoyed the two mails I have received from home Thank God all is well with my dear ones & so are the Girls & Eric. 

We are very short of officers€“ two are ill.

I still find Rutledge difficult I have had it out with him &

things are better, but I am sorry to say I am afraid they will never be quite right. He is not fit for his job & altogether too young. I wish I had an older & experienced man over me. As I am with the Guns I do not see so much of him, but it gets me out of touch with the Squadron, which will be most unfortunate a service.

Have just arranged a dinner for the N S W Mounted Rifles officers in Egypt about 16 in all to be held on the
Entry.72:
at the Continental.

The Hotels are very fine here & we have nothing like them in Australia

Several however are closed up on account of the War.

It is most embarrassing the relationship between myself & Rutledge & I am most concerned about it. He is quite impossible so far as I am concerned. I don't know how it will end, but I must speak to Onslow & the Colonel about it soon€“ it cant go on.

A was started here & we all gave 15/- each. Anexcellent enterprise & it was astonishing

quickly work was completed.

I have just been elected on a sports Committee for the Brigade: they are to be held on the 6thinst.

Have asked Mr & Mrs Perkinsto come to dinner afterwards at €“ The Continental.

I am dying for some mails€“ the last letters from home were dated the 25 January 1915.
Entry.73: Letter from Oscar dated the 18 Feby€“ nothing in it, but delighted to hear from him.
Entry.74:
Cabled to Oscar to meet & arrange for Zara & children arriving on the 16th April.

Have not been in to Cairo much lately. The truth is I have so little money€“ this business is most untoward & would have all been avoidable if I had been paid before I left Sydney by the D.P.M. Quite inexcusable treatment.

Walker at 8 PM every Monday & Friday to discuss S. Regulations.

The Colonel seems better. Still carrying the load of his

responsibilities & he has a private worry I know which is not helping him€“ I am very sorry indeed for him for he is a fine fellow

On Sunday last we visited the Barrage. First the Colonel & I went to the Arabic Museum which is full of antiquities dating from the 10thto the 14thcenturies. This however is quite modern by the side of many things in Egypt. They have a fine English Catalogue to help one out of the maze

I am still at work with the Guns. I wonder how we will get on when the real moment comes€“ sometimes I have many misgivings€“ the men however are a good lot.

Haveordered a pair of Field Boots as an experiment.

Have now made all arrangements with Cooks to store my baggage & have begun to considerthe cutting

down of all unnecessary things.

Have a little Lieut Proudfoot of the Sikhs assisting me with the Guns€“ he knows his job but I dont like him very much€“ he is too taciturn for me & we have little in common. I liked Onslow A D.C to General Broadbent very much indeed & we got on famously.

8/3/1

Went out with the Squadron & did some hard horse work. This was the first time I had done this. Rutledge did not make matters too easy, but I am determined to play the gameby him.

Young Elliott of Duntroon College I had to siton to day pretty 

Expecting Australian mails in any day. My darlings have now been at sea

on the Medina for some days & how I wonder how they are!

Telegraphed to Oscar ro look after them in case I should be suddenly called away & to feel they will have someone to look after them on their arrival in London. I expect his reply shortly.

Cannot give Zara any fresh news in my next letters to Colombo as to where we will be,

This is absolutely unknow, but I do think we are bound for Turkey€“ as the British Fleet are now concentrating on The Dardanelles, where some fine shooting is being done

Some Australians have already left Egypt for an unknown destination. This is Colonal McLaghlans 2nd Inf. Brigade.

The desert sun & sand are very trying these days.
Entry.75:
We
had
arranged a dinner by the officers of the N.SW M R in Egypt€“ 14 were present. Onslow presided & we had a jolly gathering at the Continental. Colonel Antill made a very good speech€“ he had only arrived from Australia that day.

The learning proceeds apace every day but I feel thereis so much for these fellows good mettle as they

are to know.

The Guns are doing going well & every day shows some improvement.

There are many little matters which require more adjustments to settle, but somehow one does get through all right. Keep your head all the time is the great maxim in soldiering.

General Walker is a fine fellow & a leader A Round fair head with large luminous eyes, a square jaw & an uprightfigure. Very incisive & deliberate

in his speech You feel he knows his job & what he saying to be true. He has a fine lot of ribbons.

Most fit able & reasonable & one could follow him anywhere. He his certainly made of the stuff of successful generals.

10/3/15

I have at least 2 fine little horses & they are gradually settling down, but the new fodder is making them much thinner.

Letters from home! I feel 10 years younger for a few hours after they arrive & one can scarcely describe the feelings of pleasure one has on again after so may days being in touch with those dear to him: My darling Joyce has had pneumonia. Not a word from dearest Zara about this, but Hel wrote. Of course Zara did not want to worry me, but the dear child

must now be better, otherwise they could not have left on the 3rdMarch for London. I feel they will not see me.

They are timed to arrive at Colombo on the 25thMarch & Port Said on the 6thof April; London on the 16thApril.

How I wish I could see them, but probably it is not to be, & I must reconcile myself to the position & I have done so

Mrs Suttor is with Zara.

A telegram from Oscar to day says he has arranged everything.

Eric & Stanley Benjamin have now enlisted. I am very pleased to hear that anyone has done his duty & I felt they would when they found they himself could.

We hear 10000 troops are again being sent from Australia.

Last Saturday night I entertained Mr & Mrs Perkins at the Continental Hotel. They had been

very kind & hospitable to me.

17/3/15

We get up at 5 30 am & Stables at 6 AM from that moment till bed time we have
little
few spare moments to ourselves.

Got letters from home an my dearest Z said how ill dear little Doy had been with pneumonia that she had been in Glengarlen where

the treatment was most unsatisfactory. She was very thin & it was hoped the voyage to England would do her much good.

They left by the Medina on the 3rdinst & already they are between Freemantle & Colombo & quite cut off from news of me. I live in hopes I will get a cable from Colombo on or about the 25thMarch€“ in the meantime I am very anxious about them all.

They are coming 2ndClass & I am sorry for this, as



I am sure Z will not enjoy herself so much, However she had evidently to choose between that & not coming€“ of course she could not arrange these details as well as if I had been with her poor little girl. No doubt Mr Moseshowever has done much to help her with his usual advise & counsel.

It appears to me now quite likely that they will be able to come to Cairo for a fortnight or

so, as there is no immediate prospect I think of our leaving for some weeks.

I hope indeed I will see them, but I am afraid for any disappointment these days.

Letters from the others said that Eric & Stanley Benjamin had enrolled€“ good luck to them.

Zillah has returned to N.Z, but no letters from her€“ she is a poor correspondent. She is evidently very tired of Sydney. Vera has gone home & Enid

Marks is married.

Have tried to get permanent job on the Brigade Staff, but so far it was not encouraged, consequently I have returned to the Squadron. I am most unhappy in the present position of officers. Rutledge & I are entirely unsuitable to one another. He me with the other troop leaders & has tried to get me sent to Alessia. I have done all I could

to make matters better, but I am sorry to say the position is quite an impossible & embarrassing one. I am on the point of appealing to the Colonel. Have spoken to Onslow & Higgins & I have the sympathy of both€“ it is a most unfortunate position€“ brought about by Rutledges incompetency & the fact that I have to act in a dual capacity€“ B/M Guns & 2ndin Command of the Sqn. I am much concerned & very upset at the turn of affairs.

Have been out with B Sqn during the last few days & have learnt a lot of new experiences of this work which really is entirely new to me, for I have devoted so much time to Machine Guns too much time in many ways, but it is to be hoped it will be well in the end.

I am delighted to say the Colonel has improved in health tremendously.

I had dinner on Saturday with M. €“ he had some most borish people there & I had a wretched evening. He is a fine fellow & I liked him tremendously but I told him what I thought of some of his guests!

The next day Sunday I went to the Law Courts & had a most interesting morning€“ 2 Egyptian Judges & one British in the Criminal Court which was conducted

with dignity & decorum

I was afterwards taken to the Barristers Room by one of them introduced to others had coffee & exchanged cards.

Had lunch alone at Continental Grill Room & then out to see Vernon at Heliopolis. First visited McLean in the Hospital there€“ a beautiful building. Then to 1stL H afterwards where I met some sincere old friends & officers.

Saw Meredith too. His attitude is rather strange, but I don't mind that. Vernon has had a hard time with him since leaving Australia, & he had to appeal to the Brigadier.

In the evening I visited the Mooseri family & had a most excellent evening . They remind me of the Levy-Cohen family in Sydney. They have many interests here, are very rich & respected. 

Passover is approaching & I believe some preparations are being made by the Jewish community to entertain the Jewish soldiers of whom there are a number in Cairo.

23/3/15

The anniversary of little Jacks death & poor Winifreds Birthday!

4/3/15

We fought the 1stL.H Brigade to-day fromabout 8 am to 3 PM. It was a splendid day & the biggest thing I had taken part in. Both sides did fine work. I had a great view of the operations & helped to hold the key of the position under the Colonel who did very well.

Some of the incidents were most exciting

for the country was wild & difficult.

I have now settled down to my riding & quite understand my horses which are really good beasts€“ especially "Bluey"€“ a roan.

No letters from Zara who arrives in Colombo tomorrow€“ only one from dated
Entry.76:
Had a long & very satisfactory talk with the Colonel on Sunday. We

went out together to visit an Bedouin Arabs home€“ which was interesting.We saw something of their life & they were as proud as possible of us as their visitors!

Afterwards we dined at Shepherds €“ he as my guest. He told me he quite understood the difficulties of my position with Rutledge & "to carry on" as all would be well in the end & that I was not

to worry about seeming to bethe 5thwheel on the Coach & I won't!

Visited last night Catouchi Pasha. Had dinner there €“a magnificent home & I liked them very much indeed. I will go again & had a very cordial invitation to do so.

Elliott is leaving very angrywith Rutledges . I will report him

for his conduct to day while on parade. Sorry to have to do this, but I have had quite enough of his conduct which is most disrespectful. Have had to do this through Rutledge, who of course was most dissatisfied.

25/3/15

1stL.H Brigade returned from their route march

Vernon & a dozen others dined with us tonight.

I have suffered all day from a abscess on the jaw & had to have a tooth pulled out. I had to get leave from Parade.

I hope my darlings have arrived safely & well in Colombp to day

Received a cable later saying all were well.
Entry.77:
Had a long talk with the Colonel about things Regimental. He quite understand the position

between Rutledge & myself & says he is perfectly satisfied with my work etc. This helps me a lot. He tells me that I cannot adopt a negative attitude, so now that he understands I can carry on Rutledge & I are not getting on at all, but I don't mind so muchnow in view of the Colonel's advice. I shall to Rutledge, as long as I can, but the position is very trying.

I find I get on so very much better with the fellows in the 6thwho have many more things in common with me that our other lot.

The above is written on the trainon my way to Port Said to meet Zara & the children.

The natives are absolutely overawedby our men. The farmertakes everything lying down, for all that they are very clever but slow & dirty. Their ways of living are strange.



The women are quitechattels & sleep in the yard with the animals. Their houses are devoid of furniture for the most part & very dirty.

There are hundreds of villages everywhere, made out of mud bricks.

A chief rules & his word is accepted as final in all internal disputes. Often this man has a very humble position outside for example he may be a hall porter or conductor.

The women are very



embarrassed if you approach them & quickly hide their faces behind the veil.

The sheep are a breed between goats & sheep & are all colors from brown white & black.

The children are very dirty & the way the flies cling to their eyes is appalling Most of them in consequence have very bad eyes when they reach manhood & womanhood.

The Fezis a useful article. it is said to be very cool & never blows off.

The native can sleep
