anywhere & they seem to be quite oblivious of the sun. Of course there is very little shade & the ages have enabled them to ignore the hot sun which in the middle of the day is very warm.

Our
Entry.78: L. H Brigade certainly gave a good account of themselves the other day against the
Entry.79: L. H Brigade & this did us a lot of good.
Entry.80:
The Eve of Passover. Went to Shoul & afterwards home with M. Racannuli €“ an Italian & Greek family. Received very hospitably & passed a pleasant evening & had Seder as well. The service is somewhat different to our own. The house was most refined & well furnished. They certainly understand this sort of thing here.

No Rabbi officiated & they are in their Jewish Ministers.
Entry.81:
There are now French English Australian NZ Indian & Ceylon Troops here about 200000 men at the least.

A wonderful meeting place€“ Egypt in fact is a splendid base for distribution of troops.

We are certain to go to the Dardanelles, where already fierce fighting by sea has taken place€“ so far we have lost 2 battleships & the French one. I hear some wonderful

range shooting has been carried out.

I do work intermittentlywith the Squadron & Brigade M. Guns€“ it is not altogether satisfactory, but I do my best.

I find the Brigade Major a fine fellow ready to help always. I also like the Brigadier very much, but I am afraid he is not a strong soldier€“ these Brigadiers are very small fry amongst so many seniors here.

Have had several meals during Passover at the houses of Mooseri & Cattari. I like them all very much.

Mrs Perkins also is very kind.

It is still a great inconvenience not being paid.
Entry.82: & a holiday except for Stables€“ went into Cairo & a motor drive with Higgins Weston & Suttor.
Entry.83:
Carried out a manoeuvre before General Birdwood & the Regiment shaped fairly well

Notice just viewed that many Troops are to get on the move, but the Light Horse are to be kept back for the present€“ possibly we shall go into barracks, as the summer is now coming on very quickly.

The 1stAustralian Division under General Bridges goes first to Alexandria & then on to the

Dardanelles€“ there are at least in the former place 20000 French Troops.

We have not been reviewed at all at Maadi. All the other Divisions & Brigades have had several at different times €“ the last one by General Hamilton. We are a little out of the way where there are so many others.
Entry.84:
A big street Riot in Cairo by Australian British & NZealanders. Several killed & wounded. Altogether a most unfortunate affair & great aspersions are now being cast upon us, they say are many are undisciplined & that the officers are afraid of them! Anyhow it is a thousand pities & I feel the reflection greatly.

The facts are difficult to collect, but it would appear the trouble started in an assignation

house where a N.Zr got stabbed, the house was wrecked by others, the Red cap Police were called out & fired on our fellows witout much warning. There were many thousands present. I visited the scene quietly afterward with Mce. Mooseri & I am sorry to say I observed a lot of wanton damage.

Leave is now stopped for all for going into Cairo & we want to goto Port Said so badly for Zara arrives

on Monday. Anyhow we shall abide our time.

Suttor is a fearful bluffer & really I feel he will fall in terribly one of these days€“ he blows hot & cold all the time & you simply cannot pin him down at all. I have to be very careful with him indeed. He is coming to Port Said with me & was inclined to do all sorts of things to get away, but of course he would not have dared to do any of them.

Waited patiently & word came along that we could get leave to go to Port Said to meet Zara & Mrs Suttor, so we will leave first thing on morning.
Entry.85:
Came into Cairo early & left there by 11 on train for Port Said. A dirty but interesting trip down€“ an excellent lunch is provided on the train & it is a pity they cannot do the same thing in Australia.

The Indian Troops are most impressive€“ their loyalty & efficiency are very predominant. The officers too are very competent.

Ishmalia mid-way between Cairo & Port Said was full of troops, mostly Indians.

Generals are as thick as peasin Egypt these days & Colonels are small fry indeed.

Our horses have not yet settled down to the smell & appearance of camels

I am close communication with Oscar every week & he will look after Zara the children when they arrive. This is great comfort to me.

Had nice letters from Mrs Joseph & Violet last week.

The Colonel is very generous when we are with him in town: as some slight return I have had to him to dinner with me twice€“ it is great to see him in such good form again.

It is rumored we are to have a medal for Egypt partly for the Canal affair & also to commemorate the accession of the Sultan.

I have now seen all the chief sights of Cairo & am getting a little tired of merely coming into town, but still the change from the desert is a great relief & now that dear Zara & the children are coming it will make a great difference to me

The defences on the Canal were most complete.Coming up through the Canal we saw one side of each, now on journey to Port Said by Rail we are able to see the other sides Some of the troops have dug themselves right into the Ground

I am sorry to say there are very few who have recd anything at all in the Regiment.

Higgins & I get on famously & I am sorry

he has not yet got his Captaincy.

I have never seen a more united family than the Mooseri one. They are all in mourning for a young Son aged 25 who died about 6 months ago.

Arrived in Port Said at 4.30 PM. Suttor & I went round & investigated the place. Tried to see the British Consul for Pass Ports for Zara & Mrs S, but found out afterwards by enquiry

same was not necessary as we were here to meet them.

Met some nice people on their way to England on the train, after having seen their sons off to the front from here.

Met some of the R N Division fellows€“ there are 11000 here & they consist of all the Naval Brigade Units collected together. They are organised as Infantry, wear the names of Battleships & have bands on their khaki uniforms to

correspond with the similar ranks in the Navy. Many of the officers are very young indeed. They had not met any of the Australians till they met me.

Yarned with an interesting American till 11 PM€“ the boat is expected at 10.30 am in the morning.
Entry.86:
Up early & met a curious fellow named Chard who had been with & was going to England

to reform the Worcester Regiment€“ he did not like the want of discipline in our forces & undoubtedly it is a real failing, but one cannot expect anything different considering how our forces have been raised & bustled away.

Zara & Children arrived safely. They are very well & were in fact sorry to leave the ship where they had made many friends€“ even getting used to the 2ndClass where Zara very bravely

had gone to save money€“ she is real little brick. I am delighted to have them.

We left for Cairo at once & what a day €“ the train€“ a "hamseen" was blowing & the heat & dust were awful.

To Hotel Continental where things got better for they have a lovely big room & are ever so much more comfortable.

Mrs Suttor & Zdo not get on & I am very sorry.

Was a little disappointed

that Zara did not know one or two things about my affairs in Australia, as I was relying so much on this, especially as to my back pay etc, which is still outstanding! This since
Entry.87:
Sept 1914!!

I did not stop in tonight having said I would return by 1. AM tram to Maadi. This evidently also upset Zara & I only acted out of a sheer sense of duty & much against my personal wishes, still duty is duty all the time & nothing

will ever make me see otherwise.

The children are well but Doy is thin & a little pale. They are so dear to me.

Poor Mr Moses, from Zara is simply wonderful & his efforts & work for her before her departure were absolutely super-human almost. I am really greatly in his debt & her accountof what he had done & the letters he wrote her absolutely broke me up.

I have had to cable

him for some money, as Zara's has gone direct to London on account of her uncertainty about stopping here. I did not like doing this, but there was nothing else to do.

MrsStokes has been very kind in advising me how to act here & will be a great help to Zara generally. Her husband left for Turkey about 4 weeks ago.

Zara I know will thoroughly appreciate life at the Hotel

There is no doubt Zara has been a real little Trojan since my departure & Doys illness gave her great worry & trouble.

It appears now she was quite happy at "Luton". If I had realized this, I would not have sent for her, but have no regrets at having done so, for the experience for her & the youngsters will be a splendid one.

Took them to the Citadel & the Zoo on Sunday. They did appreciate all

they saw.

We met a charming man there named Colonel Anderson Director of Stores who paid us a lot of attention showing us over the military factory & afterwards entertained us in his quarters.He had a fine collection of antiquities & bric a brac

Received a cable for£80 from Mr Moses.

Letters from Oscar who is well. He is offended with Mr Moses & does not understand that he

cannot draw Bills without notice, as we have very little money at current account & the Banks will not grantan overdraft. I have written to him endorsing Mr M's action. Oscar has bought several articles of equipment for me in London.

Zara is already been invited out a good deal & likes the friends I have made here very much indeed.
Entry.88:
It is very trying these days on the desert. Soon we shall have to modify our working hours although we are not working what I call hard at all.

The Colonel quite understands me & I am very fond of him. He understands his job well.

One of our fellows has just returned from Alexandria & he was associated while there with the Foreign Legion! This equals all my imagination.

The Hotels here have set themselves out to be courteous & considerate to all of us, especially if you are their resident. Zara is very happy at the Continental in consequence, but we must go slow with our money.

Mr Gum has placed his garden at our disposal€“ it is on & a beautiful spot.

All the
Entry.89:
Australian Division have now left here & were followed by the Australian & NZ

Division being known as the Australian & NZArmy Corps. This is exclusive of the Light Horse for the Dardanelles Peninsula is no place for them. I am certain Australia will now make a name for herself, but the cost is going to be very heavy. Already provision is being made for 70000 casualties!

Our horses have now been clipped & are making some improved on the Egyptian fodder
Entry.90:
We are getting up a Dinner & Ball at Haloman€“ by the officers of this Brigade. I hope Zara & I will both be able to go.

A VenetianCarnival at Shepherds on Saturday Night was a charming picture €“ nearly all the conventions were dropped & Zara thoroughly enjoyed herself. She is looking very well & black does so suit her.



I am not doing very much Machine Gun work now, but have been with the Squadron the last few weeks. Rutledge & I seem to be getting on better. I hope so & that it will be permanent.

I find it somewhat expensive going into dinner to Cairo & will in future go after Mess. Have given up the Secretaryship of the Mess €“ I have been at it for so long that I think others should now have a shot at the work.
Entry.91:
I have omitted to enter up my days & impressions for a fortnight or so. The reasons are somewhat varied€“ chiefly because I have had a good deal on my mind during this time. The Children have not been well having suffered somewhat from the effects of .

Zara has had lots of invitations & is really facinated with Cairo & so are the children & I hope this experience for them will last all their lives for both are

very observant.

It is a great delight to me to take them everywhere & everyone here who I have made the acquaintance of has been very kind.

Zara has worriedme a good deal herself. The dearest little girl in the world she is to me & nothing she can do will every alter my great & deep affection for her, but she does such wilfulthings & nothing she enjoys more than a good flirtation€“ she has now another with Higgins the Adjutant. I have spoken to them

 (see over two pages)

both, people are talking & she allows Higgins to monopolise her time & attention at my expense & I find now constantly he is in her company.

It does so upset me (not from any spirit of jealousy although I am jealous indeed of her good name) but because it causes her name to be bandied about makes a fool of me & the practiceis so dangerous & it means so much to the 4 of us who are so alone in the world, but she will not desist

& I have to put up with all the annoyance. It seems so strange to me; she comes all these thousands of miles to be with me & here is the result. Throughout I have the greatest confidence in her self control & character, but who can tell what all this will lead to.

Higgins himself under a cloakof fine manners has for the time facinated her, proved a false friend to me & there me. I love, of course, for Zara to have all the pleasure she can, but seems a little cruel

of her to act so, just as I am on the point of going away right to the front, perhaps never to return. However nothing can alter the great love for her that I have & perhaps some day she may more readily realise what a very real anxiety she has given me, but I do not complain so very much for the dear children are absolutely devoted to me & quite understand. Zara makes as her excuse that I am far too serious for her & says although she has a deep regard for me, finds very often

she cannot put up with the situation & hates the idea of the marriage tie. All this has meant much talk & tears & I have now gone through it so often that I ought perhaps to be somewhat used to this experience, but can a man devoted to his wife ever get used to others always being with her & the feeling that he himself is an & is not wanted. Zara herself says she is sorry & knows my feelings & cannot understand so she says that I can still continue to love her, but I do all the more with the usual worlds & human's contrariness

Inwardly I trust in God & have the feeling that all will be well in the end & this alone can at present be my comfort.

Who would have thought that when I left her in Australia a few months ago I would have this load of trouble ever again for she was indeed my loving little wife her whole thought & attention being for me & mine, but I will try not to complain for I love her with all my heart & soul.

Sometimes I think I must be greatly to blame & must

be a very trying person to live with on account of my seriousness & earnestness in all things.

Higgins I find is Respondent in a Divorce suit & that his history is the usual adventurers one. His name is not Higgins & altogether his past is what these facinating white-haired irresponsible mens always are. It is so easy for them to break up a happy home when it all means so little to them.

And I am on the Eve of leaving my dear ones! I write with the greatest pain & distress

I find that I am getting on much better with Rutledge & generally things Regimental are much happier.

Each mail brings me news from homeall are well & Oscar keeps me well informed every week of his own welfare & that of his wife & child.

Eric has now joined the Expeditionary Forces, but I have no idea who he is with & when he leaves Australia..

Since I wrote last there has been an attempted assassination of the Sultan. A Court Martial tried & condemned the prisoner who was executed a few days ago. He was a individual. The Court was conducted with all solemnity & the list counsel engaged for the prisoners defence. I could not get off to attend.

Troops have now landed in the Dardanelles & any day will come word for us to move. We hear few particulars of

I spend every night in Cairo nearly with the Children & Zara€“ the Colonel allows me when I am not on duty to do this. I am trying to arrange for them to come out to Maadi.

Took the children to some French Sports the other day. The foreign atmosphere

I have a new batman who is a most excellent fellow.

Entry.92:
My darling little Geof is suffering from the effects of Sun. He got some when in Camp out here with me at Maadi: No children should be allowed out now after 11€“ till 4 PM. He looks terribly ill & I am very anxious about him, but he is so brave & uncomplaining.

While fresh in my mind I must also record

another great worry & following on what I have already written above. I had felt all the afternoon while with Zara she was very irritable & had something on her mind. While with the children tonight Higgins rang her up€“ I gathered this only, but proved correct afterwards. We had some sort of dinner together, but by no means were we happy.

Afterwards after seeing that the Children were happily placed & in bed, I went to sit with her on the Piazza of the Hotel. She then admitted that she was waiting for me to go & for Higgins

Need I say how upset I am, but I know I have got to put up with it, for I cannot make a scene or take any action. This Zara knows & here I am one of the unhappiest of men because she has this infatuation after coming these thousands of miles to see me. The result is I am not seeing her at all, as I want to & it seems so cruel to me

My love will be in the children, but I cannot alter my affection for Zara who has done so much & meant so much for me in the past.

She describes Higgins as the "moth round the candle" & simply enjoys leading men such as he on. Some men who were treated so would soon take action, but I cannot for my childrens good name & future is always present before me, but I am the most miserable of men & I really do think I have tried to do my duty to Zara who curiously says she still

has a great affection for me. I can only trust to time & circumstance & rely on my God as the way out.

This morning I watched carefully some goings of Native prisoners all in irons who work close by our Camp. Some are 25 yearmen & all range from 7 years to life sentences. What an outlook. There are 3 classes & they are 2000 in all guarded by 300 Soldiers & 150 Warders

They are always interested in us when we pass them every day.
